image.altText: A man stands on a balcony with a frown on his face.

items.synopsis: Insurance companies have responded to back-to-back floods and soaring building costs by hiking premiums by around 30 per cent in just one year. But for the riskiest homes, cover is either refused outright, or offered at prices few can afford.Â

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Online shopping took off during the pandemic, and now with the rising cost-of-living, more of us are being careful with how we spend our hard earned money â€” even on the essentials. Have you changed how you do your weekly (or fortnightly, or monthly!) shop for those household and grocery items that are traditionally more expensive â€” like dishwashing tablets, nappies, cleaning products, or that one specific product you just can't find in store? Are you jumping online to get the best possible deal on Amazon, Coles, Woolworths, or another online store? If that sounds like you, we want to hear from you! Business reporter Emily Stewart is exploring how our grocery shopping habits have changed for a story with ABC News â€” if you want to share your story, get in touch with her by emailing Stewart.Emily@abc.net.au .

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A new report from Anglicare Australia has found those living on the poverty line often end up paying more for essentials, because they can't afford to shop around or buy in bulk. The Poverty Premium report found those on lower incomes are spending 61 per cent more on insurance, 93 per cent more on groceries, and 142 per cent more on phone data. Anglicare Australia's executive director, Kasy Chambers, told ABC News Breakfast that the Federal Government's current cost of living relief measures aren't having a tangible impact on those who need it most. "The way out of this poverty premium is to not have people living in poverty, the number one thing is to raise income support payments above the poverty line and we've still got those stage three tax cuts on the paper there pushing money to the richer end of town."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Poor people pay more for groceries

children.content: A new report from Anglicare Australia has found those living on the poverty line often end up paying more for essentials, because they can't afford to shop around or buy in bulk.
report found those on lower incomes are spending 61 per cent more on insurance, 93 per cent more on groceries, and 142 per cent more on phone data.
Anglicare Australia's executive director, Kasy Chambers
, told ABC News Breakfast that the Federal Government's current cost of living relief measures aren't having a tangible impact on those who need it most.

"The way out of this poverty premium is to not have people living in poverty, the number one thing is to raise income support payments above the poverty line and we've still got those stage three tax cuts on the paper there pushing money to the richer end of town."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Australian share market remains in the red at lunchtime, but it's recovered some ground. The ASX 200 index has dropped 0.2 per cent to 7,180. Most sectors are in the red with energy stocks and banks weighing on the index. Petrol refiner and service station owner Viva Energy (-7 per cent) has slumped on a media report that major shareholder Vitol could trim its stake. Miners are doing the best thanks to higher copper and iron ore prices. Liontown Resources shares are down 0.3 per cent to $3.00 after Gina Rinehart's Hancock Prospecting raised its stake. Last week, Liontown accepted a $6.6 billion takeover bid from global lithium giant Albemarle. Best and worst performers: Telix Pharmaceuticals: +3.5% Megaport: +2.3% Ingenia Communities: +1.9% Viva Energy: -7.3% Syrah Resources: -5.7% Chalice Mining: -5.7%
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Australian market comes off its lows
